Massachusetts General Laws Ch. 186, \u00.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws Ch. 186, § 14(1) states that every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, entitling a tenant to peaceful and undisturbed possession of the leased premises.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.2d 1313 (Mass. 1977)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Caselaw such as Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.2d 1313 (Mass. 1977) and Phipps v. Clark, 390 Mass. 998 (1983) reaffirm the landlord's duty to maintain leased premises in a habitable condition under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway at all; it is a criminal case concerning a private citizen’s use of deadly force in making a citizen’s arrest. It does not address landlord-tenant law, habitability, or the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, this opinion cannot support the proposition about a landlord’s duty to maintain habitable premises under an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “The central question in this case is whether the defendant was justified in using deadly force… We turn now to consideration of the defendant’s claim that he was justified in using deadly force to prevent the escape of the two men from his attempt to make a citizen’s arrest.”

Phipps v. Clark, 390 Mass. 998 (1983).proposition: Caselaw such as Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.2d 1313 (Mass. 1977) and Phipps v. Clark, 390 Mass. 998 (1983) reaffirm the landlord's duty to maintain leased premises in a habitable condition under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
